Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 09:03AM katie11 wrote: Dear Pee, I am so very sorry you've been given this news.  I am also wondering why you were given this time line? The only time I was given an expiry date was when I was first diagnosed with Stage IV from the get go.  A rather ignorant breast surgeon looked at my mammo and ultrasound scans and told me I had 2 years to live!  I hadn't asked his opinion.  That was 4 and a half years ago. Since then I've never asked how long the docs think I have left.  I am pretty sure that when things really start to deteriorate that I will know myself and, in any case, no one can really tell you how long- it depends entirely on how you respond to treatment. Only a few months ago, I was preparing myself for the inevitable when the disease suddenly took a turn for the worst.  As it turns out, I have responded well to the latest treatment and have managed a fabulous Christmas with my wonderful family. You are right to prepare yourself and get your affairs in order.  For the sake of ourselves and our loved ones, we all need to do that but try not to dwell on time frames.  Instead, enjoy every moment with your lovely family that you can take.  The decision to stop all treatment and turn to palliative care is indeed going to be the hardest choice we are ever going to have to take.  I like to feel - at least I hope - that I will instinctively know when enough is enough and will be at peace with the decision.  This is probably a fantasy on my part.  The one thing I have repeatedly said to my onc is that I am prepared to go on trying new treatments as long as there are options out there (which I know there are) and as long as my quality is life is good (which it currently is).  What treatments have you had to date?  If you let us know, we may be able to suggest alternatives to discuss with your onc.  Don't give up unless you are ready to and stay strong! You are in my thoughts!

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2008 10:29AM katie11 wrote: CalGal, what a beautifully written and thoughtful post.  I hadn't realised you'd received your diagnosis just after your marriage - I am so sorry. Lesley - if you let it, the fear of what may lie ahead can eat away at you and destroy what life you have here and now.  I've been living with mets for nearly 2 years now and I can't say that the fear has gone away, but I've learnt how to control it a little better.  The day I woke up about a month after my diagnosis and realised that I was spending so much time obsessing about my disease and that it was taking away the sheer pleasure of being in the company of those I love, was the day I decided that cancer was not going to rule my life. Whatever the future may hold for me, I am lucky enough to have a wonderful life here and now that I enjoy, surrounded by people I love and who love me back.  I've learnt how to live more for the moment, enjoy simple pleasures and it's amazing how things that used to stress me out and anger me, be it at home or work, don't touch me at all now. Also, like CalGal, apart from those I am closest to, I haven't made my mets diagnosis general knowledge.  I find this ignorance much easier to deal with than the continuous worry and concern of others (albeit genuine) that can be overwhelming and all consuming at times. Finally, when the fear really takes hold, I have a good cry, a warm hug with my DH and I come here where there are other women walking the same path and really understand what I'm going through.  There are many women here who I have found truly inspirational. Hugs, Katie xx

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2010 02:58AM katie11 wrote: First of all, thank you to all of you for the big kick up the backside which prompted me to get myself into ER on Sunday and it's just as well I did.  Apart from/because of the ascites, I also had very low blood oxygen counts, very low blood pressure and was very dehydrated.  They inserted what they called a 'drainage' device into the back of the abdomen which stayed there for a couple of days and, during that time, they drained 6 litres of fluid (yes, that really is right - 6 litres!).  No wonder I couldn't eat/drink/sleep/sit/stand blah, blah, blah.  Initially, the feeling of release from the pressure was fabulous but then I got severe stomach cramps, had to have the doc called to my bedside in the night who removed the drain and gave me a shot of morphine.  Now, there's no doubt that morphine truly is a remarkable drug as far as its pain killing powers are concerned, but it also knocks you right  off planet earth in the process.  I spent the next two days vomiting and sleeping, sleeping and vomiting as a result.  Anyhoo, I'm at home again now and still feeling iffy and hugging the bucket!   Here's the weird bit ... while I was in they reviewed my recent CT scan results with me which show NED in lungs, liver etc, so they are a bit mystified as to where the ascites is coming from. Next steps are interesting as they are asking me to consider a clinical trial.  I don't know much about it yet and will be meeting with the onc on Monday to discuss but it will involve taking a pill which works by cutting off the blood supply to the tumour and therefore making it die,  DIE, DIE!! Anyone doing a trial like this at the mo?  I will post when I have more info.  Thank you again for all your excellent advice.  Seriously, what would I do without you all? Katie xoxox

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 04:58AM katie11 wrote: I managed to get some benefit from Tamoxifen for over a year but, after that, a couple more hormonals (Arimidex and Megace) failed me and I had the wildfire you describe.  It's all over the bones (not marrow - so no experience there) but it spread to the abdomen and ovaries and I also had one lesion on the liver.  It was then too risky to try other hormonals as they can take a while to kick in and we just couldn't wait so moved onto chemo.  CMF first which probably saved my life a year ago but didn't have lasting effects unfortunately and I am now on Taxotere which is working well.  Sometimes we need to get out the big guns to get it all under control.  If I am very, very lucky and this current regime stabilises the disease, I will try to persuade my onc to try another hormonal.  You never know - there is hope!  I was given the 'talk' a month ago and even introduced to a palliative care team.  Now I am walking around again and feeling good. My motto is 'hope for the best, but prepare for the worst!'   Hope you are feeling better today.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2011 03:08AM katie11 wrote: I'm not triple negative but I have taken a number of chemo breaks over the past 5 years of treatment. The latest one was missing a couple of treatments of Navelbine recently when I had an infection and again due to poor blood test results. If you don't take a break when your body needs it, you put your general health at risk as our bodies can't fight off even the smallest of infections. Blood transfusions will help boost your blood counts and make you feel less tired. I've had a couple and always feel better as a result. Remember also that the chemo in your body will continue to work long after the last infusion.

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2007 07:55PM - edited Sep 7, 2007 07:56PM by katie11 Wendy darling - I am so sorry that you have been going through all of this. I've been having trouble with board access all week since the upgrade and just managed to log in successfully now to find your message! I've heard some refer to breast cancer as a 'gift' before and personally I really struggle with this idea.  Though this journey has changed me in many many ways as a person and though some of these changes have helped me reprioritise my life in ways that I think have made me better as a human being, I would balk at the idea of calling cancer a 'gift.'  The bottom line is that it's a terrible disease that is killing many wonderful women on a daily basis leaving families devasted.  Gift? I think not. Oh, Wendy, I'm so sorry about Tyler!  Our automatic reactions as parents is to feel guilt when bad things happen to our children and my most painful emotional battles with this disease have been fought when I think about the possibility of not being there in the future when my children will need their mother at their side.  Don't feel guilty, Wendy - Tyler was not in any great pain and there is no way that you could have known that he had appendicitis.  You found out what it was precisely because you are a caring mom and took Tyler to ER to be on the safe side. I wish I was there to hug you, Wendy, but consider this a virtual hug.  Katie xx

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2008 09:02AM katie11 wrote: Hi Maria, It sounds like your onc is on the ball and getting everything done that is necessary.  Out of all the scans that I've done since my stage 4 diagnosis, the bone scan is the easiest.  It's just a bit of a drag as you have to wait for quite a long time after the injection before they can scan.  The scan itself is easy and in no way painful - you just lie there basically and the machine is 'open' so there's nothing claustrophobic about it. Is your mum ER, PR+?  Her onc may suggest starting with a hormone treatment if she is and this is not at all aggressive or painful. Hope the scan turns out to be B9 in any case; it could be just artheritis after all! Katie xx

Posts.Title: How do you tell your child about cancer? ead raro

Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 03:18AM katie11 wrote: Jenn, I can really sympathise with you and can feel your frustration in your post! I recently went through an infection and progression at the same time and have never experienced fatigue like it. I gave up doing all my normal activities and just took to my bed. I slept on and off all day every day. The sleep wasn't at all refreshing but I couldn't do anything but sleep. I would fall asleep in the middle of 'conversations' with family. I can't lie - I had many thoughts about the possibility of just going to sleep and not waking up again. I welcomed the idea. I couldn't walk and I couldn't eat. I didn't even have the strength to turn over in bed. Yet, here I am sitting here now and things have completely turned around. There is hope though it's difficult to see any light at the end of the tunnel when you're feeling so bad as you are just now. What are for most healthy people simple infections can be absolutely debilitating to us and can take so long to recover from. What you need to do just now is rest and sleep. Just give in to it and allow the time your body needs to recover from the infection. Don't try and carry on as normal because things just aren't normal just now. Sleep and recover! Thinking of you!

When I last had progression - about 2 months ago - I was bedridden and slept all day every day. I thought that I was going to drift away in my sleep. In fact, I had a few dreams that my time had come. I welcomed the sensation; it was peaceful and not at all frightening. But I started a new treatment (Navelbine funnily enough) and since then, things have just got better and better. Next week we are going on a family holiday! I don't know how things have changed so drastically but they have and I am happy to be looking forward to going on a family holiday. Stopping treatment is such a personal decision. Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 11:40AM katie11 wrote: I am chiming in a bit late here but have only just had time to read all the posts and catch up on the thread. Whilst I feel we should be grateful in many ways for all the awareness and funds the 'pink' campaign has raised for breast cancer over the years, I also feel slightly uncomfortable with the subtle messages it tends to put across.  In the first place, the choice of the colour pink is an intriguing one.  We associate pink with a certain type of femininity which I personally can't relate to at all.  When you combine the colour with the almost celebratory atmosphere of the events and endless survivor stories, I end up feeling totally alienated from the whole process - like the ugly friend in an otherwise perfect line-up of beautiful people.  I just want to disappear into a dark corner somewhere so that I won't spoil the atmosphere at the party.  At these gatherings we are constantly reminded to make sure we go for early detection and never forget our yearly mammos when, in fact, so many of us here were diagnosed at such a young age and well before we were even supposed to be thinking about getting checked out. We are also spoken to about statistics and how many are now 'cured' and are 'survivors.'  I don't know, perhaps it's all my fault - I just didn't fight damn hard enough!

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2011 07:25AM katie11 wrote: Important question! I hope your onc can come up with an answer as none of us want to reject a treatment that might actually have been working. The issue with Faslodex is that it can take a long time (my onc said 3-6 months) to actually kick in and be able to tell whether it is working or not. This has to be measured against how quickly the disease is progressing so the annoying thing about Faslodex is that you have to be relatively stable in the first place to give it a go. I've been doing the Faslodex shots for about 6 months now but in combination with Navelbine. Something's working though I don't know for sure what! Good luck and let us know what your onc says! Katie

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 08:04AM katie11 wrote: Welcome to the club no one wants to be a member of!  You're right - it's their loss on the other board.  I simply don't understand that attitude out there about women with mets. It's as if some feel they might catch them by just talking to you!  Silly! There are wonderful people on these boards with wonderful advice.  I don't have brain mets myself but there are quite a few here that do and are responding well to treatments.  BUT you don't know the results yet and headaches can be caused by lots of things including good old fashioned stress, which, unsurprisingly, is not infrequent in our situation!  I had a scare a year ago - problems with balance and hearing - but the scan came back clean and the symptoms were just a side effect of the chemo I was on at the time.  It's hard, I know, but try to hang on there until those results.  No point ruining your time now worrying about the future none of us are certain about! Positive vibes coming your way for good results!

Posts.Title: How do you say goodbye? Nanalinda konakat

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 05:45AM katie11 wrote: No one can answer this question for any of us, unfortunately.  All we can do is relate personal experiences but they are just that - personal experiences.  Everyone is different and everyone travels a different journey with this disease.  What I have tried to learn to do is to live my life as best as possible with the disease rather than allowing the disease dictate my life for me.  In the 4 years I have been Stage IV, I have changed jobs and even changed countries.  Later this month, I will move into a new house we have just bought.  I have made plans for my next holiday and even Christmas.  The trick is to make sure you have everything covered just in case things change quickly - which they can do!  On a personal note, I can tell you that I have been in remission twice - once for over a year and once for an all to brief 6 weeks!  There are others who have been NED with Stage IV on these boards for more than 10 years, however.  Who knows?  Just live your life the way you want to live it and enjoy!  Try not to spend all the time 'fretting' as my mum used to say!  Easier said than done, I know.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 04:56AM - edited Jan 20, 2009 08:26AM by katie11 The old emotional yo yo effect is a standard feature of the stage 4 boards as you can imagine.  I call it an emotional roller coaster and, believe me, it's been one big ride since my diagnosis of stage 4 from the get go 2 and a half years ago.  I remember I spent the first 6 months crying every day and then one day - can't remember how this happened - I came to what seemed like a very logical conclusion to me which has helped change my life with cancer.  That is, none of us here know how long we will have left. Whether it's 2 years, 10 or even more, why spend that time focusing on the end?  Instead, I got up, brushed myself down and carried on with the much more interesting and exciting job of living.  Since my diagnosis, I've been on lots of fantastic memorable holidays with my two beautiful girls (they are now 10 and 12), I've also moved to live in a new country and started a new and exciting job. Believe you me, I know it is easier said than done, but go and have a ball with your kids on this holiday.  You'll never completely be able to put cancer behind you (it's flitting around my mind most of the time), but you can take back control of your life and get on with living again! Have fun! Katie xxx

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 05:52AM katie11 wrote: Jenn, I feel your frustration and completely understand your anger with this disease. It is so, so difficult to plan ahead with this disease as it's impossible to know what's round the corner. Is there any chance of taking some immediate short term absence from work to give you some time to come to terms with the immediate situation? You also need time to gather all the information and reach some conclusions about where the disease actually is, what your treatment is best, how you feel and of course how you respond to treatment. It will also give you some time to be with your family. When I was first diagnosed with mets from the get go, I had one year off work. The benefits were almost equivalent to my salary so there was little financial loss. I did a grueling chemo regime and underwent surgery to remove the original tumor. By the end of that year I was stable and returned to work. Just a thought to buy yourself some thinking time!

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 11:59AM katie11 wrote: Hi, Fluid build up in the abdomen is quite common in breast cancer patients.  I also suffered from this last summer but didn't go to see my onc as soon as I should have done when alarm bells were ringing.  By the time I got to see her, the fluid had spread into the legs and behind the lungs.  I was given immediate relief through a puncuture in the abdomen.  This is a simple and painless procedure and allows the fluid to drain out and releases the pressure.  You should go to see your onc asap, though.  Don't wait until your next appointment. The burden of the fluid build up led to the loss of use of my legs and I am now only just beginning to walk again. Please feel free to PM me if you want to and good luck! Katie xoxo

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2011 10:41PM katie11 wrote: I've been on these boards for 5 years now and have grieved over many women who we have lost along the way. Sometimes I actually feel bemused and even guilty that I am still here. But I am, at least for the moment. Yes, it is frightening but the only thing we can do is to carry on living each day at a time and enjoying the time we have with those we love. Don't waste time and emotional energy analyzing the statistics when there are so many better things to do. My girls are 15 and 12 now and there's not a day goes by without me giving them a hug, telling them I love them and how proud I am of them. They have a great sense of humor and we also share lots of laughter. Live and enjoy the moment and try not to grieve too much about the future; we none of us know how long we have.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2010 05:35AM katie11 wrote: I have also had ascities which I had drained twice and has now gone away. I still have the constipation though and spoke to my dietician about it.  She puts it down to the chemo and advices against taking laxatives.  I am happy about this as it tended to have the opposite effect and led to some embarrassing situations!! The dietician gave me the following advice for a more natural solution: 1. More exercise is essential for treatment of constipations 2. Eat calmly, do not skip any meals.  Eat preferably six small meals a day to keep the intestines working.  Eat at regular times as our bodies prefer regularity (biorhthym) 3. Eat at least 2 portions of fruit every day and no less than 3-4 spoonfuls of vegetables.  This should not include too many raw vegetables. 4. Products with active culture are good (yogurt, for example) 5. Drink at least 1 and a half to 2 litres a day. 6. Acidic and/or fibre rich products  - not too much - promote good bowel movement. 7.  Take your time when going to the toilet.  Take something to read in order to wait calmly for something to happen. 8. One good method to encourage to foster regularity is to sit on the toilet for 5 minutes every morning after breakfast without straining.  After a while your body will learn that the moment has come.  Place a foot stool under your feet. 9. Holding it up promotes constipation so as soon as you feel the urge to go to the toilet, go! 10. If you feel that you are getting cramps, go to the toilet but do not strain. 11.  After going to the toilet, allow your body to rest and do not eat straight away. 12.  Avoid fatty foods, chocolate, white rice, white bread, bananas, buscuit rusks, strong tea and hard boiled eggs. 13. Freshly squeezed orange juice can work wonders at breakfast and is also an excellent source of Vitimin C. Also drink the squeezed pulp. Also drink a large glass of warm water on an empty stomach. 14. For breakfast, a lice of whole meal bread with jam and a piece of fruit?freshly squeezed juice, dried prunes with a cup of coffee stimulates the peristaltic movement of the intestines. 15. You may also hae yogurt with muesli for breakfast.  A good muesli consists of various types of grains, dried fruits and nuts and seeds.  Always let the muesli sit for 15 minutes to give it time to absorb the liquid and makes it easier to digest. Adding fresh fruit makes the muesli more nutritious too. Choose mango, pear, melon, mandarin, strawberries.  Vary this breakfast with a breakfast of bread TIP: Brush your teeth after a breakfast of muesli and yogurt because the menthol taste of toothpaste does not go well with fruit and yogurt. 16.  Use laxatives sparingly as they make the intenstines lazy. I hope some of this advice helps.  It has certainly changed my life.  Before this, I was in hospital for 2 weeks for an intenstinal infections caused by the constipation.  Good luck! Katie xxx

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2010 12:26PM katie11 wrote: Chiming in a bit late here, but here goes!  There is so much contradictory information out there that these issues to do with what to eat/what not to eat have become very confusing!  There's hardly a day goes by without opening the newspaper to discover something else can possibly cause cancer, or indeed, cure it!  I've also lost count of the number of phone calls/emails/cut out articles that have been sent to me by well meaning friends and family members  over the past 4 years about the latest 'thing.'  Every time I speak to my mother on the phone, she asks me if I am drinking green tea as she read an article about it being a cancer cure once!  To tell you the truth, it drives me crazy.  The latest was a study a colleague at work passed to my DH called The China Study that advocated eating ONLY veggies, fruit, nuts and absolutely NO dairy, meat, bread, sugar etc.  Honestly, you could jump from one fad diet to another and make yourself miserable through whatever time you have left by denying yourself constantly.   I've come to one conclusion wading through all of this.  Yes, diet and exercise are important because they are, of course, going to help and support your body as you fight the disease, help you boost your immune system and generally feel better.  They are not going to cure your cancer, however!  Denial is a miserable way to spend time, also.  Yes, eat healthily - fruit, green leafed veggies, whole grain and yes, drink lots of water to flush out the toxins.  I also happen to like a cup of green tea during the day.  BUT I am not going to make the rest of my life miserable in the process; a glass or two of good red wine in the evening shared over a family evening meal is wonderful, so is occasionally enjoying some chocolate.  Is eliminating these things really going to save me from my Stage IV diagnosis?  i don't think so!  As far as exercise is concerned, DH and I take an evening stroll round the local park with the dogs - it's good exercise and a chance for some quality time in each other's company too.  To cut a long story short, enjoy your life, be sensible and everything in moderation! Good luck!

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 08:27AM katie11 wrote: Hi Elaine! It's good to see you posting again; I've missed you!  It's wonderful news on your daughter- this will take time but progress is being made and it really sounds as if she is herself now ready to move forward which is such a big step in the right direction.  With all of your continued, love, support and encouragement, she will get better! You and I have had similar experiences and disappointments recently and I fully understand what you are going through right now.  You may remember, a few months back I was also told that options were running out,  One treatment after another failed me, the palliative care team were called in and I was told to prepare for the worst.  Well, I've just posted the news I have got today which I hope will provide you with some inspiration and encouragement.  Taxotere is a drug I used in the past - about four years ago now- it worked then and, for the moment, it is working again now.  I was similarly shocked by the 'running out of options' statement.  I know there are still lots of drugs out there but I also realise that when one treatment after another fails and the disease is progressing, the doctors become less hopeful.  I think this is why they say these things.  It's horrilbe to hear, I know, but, it's important to be given the opportunity to hear it and have time to process it.  Having said that, things can and do turn around.  Look where I am today in comparison to just a few short months ago.  I am really sorry about missing the appointment about the possible trial because of the snow.  Remember it's still there for a future option, however, and, you never know, Taxol may well be the drug that works for you. Keeping you in my thoughts, Elaine, and don't be a stranger to the boards! Happy Christmas, honey! Katie xoxo

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 04:30AM katie11 wrote: I have some pain issues in the abdomen area which are down to mets. It usually gets worse after I've eaten and I can almost feel the food getting blocked as it moves along the intestines. I started Navelbine a month ago and the pain has decreased and the general feel of the area has improved which I am taking as a sign the treatment is working. Scans are unreliable in this area as mets can be difficult to see here. My onc is usually more reliant on physical exams of the area and how I am feeling generally. It's certainly worth mentioning at your appointment on Wednesday. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 07:00AM katie11 wrote: I've also read 'The China Study' - it was lent to me by a well meaning colleague from work and it is indeed a very interesting and compelling read. However, it is also only one of literally hundreds of books, theories and hypothesis about the recent alarming rise in the number of people being diagnosed with breast cancer each year in western countries. They announced on the news in the UK yesterday that the number of women who will be diagnosed in the UK with this disease has now risen to one in eight! Wow! They also put this rise down to many changes in our lifestyles such as diet, obesity, drinking, smoking, lack of exercise, blah, blah, blah... Whilst I am sure that all of the above no doubt heighten the risk of contracting the disease, they do not cause it and avoiding the above does not prevent it either. We have daily proof of this right here on the boards. Healthy lifestyle choices may lower our risks but they do not eliminate them and are certainly not some kind of miracle cure as suggested in Jane Plant's book. To suggest so is offensive, patronizing and a HUGE oversimplification of what is a very complex issue. It also very conveniently places the blame at the individual's door and fails to address much wider social and political issues. For example, anyone who has read Rachel Carlson's 'Silent Spring' will know the kind of thing I am referring to. I am so happy for you if the non dairy route has worked for you or that drinking green tea has cured your cancer or indeed if not eating red meat has saved your life. However, for every one who feels they have cured in this way, there are literally hundreds more who haven't. If only it was that easy!
Posts.Title: Why don't Chinese women get breast cancer? MCTHO

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 08:31AM katie11 wrote: Supermom101, I rarely get involved in controversy on the boards; it is a place I like to come to for comfort and support and one of the few places where people really understand me as they struggle through daily life with a Stage IV diagnosis. However, I don't think you've quite understood why your comments are considered insensitive and patronizing by many here. Both of your references to prevention as a cure and, indeed, Dr Weiss' column about diet are inappropriate on a Stage IV forum as theyseem to suggest that there is something we could have done to prevent the situation we are in. Equally, you also make reference to facts and statistics you have at hand that you could use to prove your case though you choose not to. This is also patronizing to say the least. However, I am an intelligent, well educated, well read individual who is perfectly capable of making up my own mind. Noone here is disputing the fact that diet plays an important role in this and, indeed, many other diseases that are growing at such an alarming rate in western society. However, whilst adopting a healthier diet may lower your risks of a breast cancer diagnosis, it is not going to prevent you being diagnosed and is certainly not going to cure you. As I said above, there are much wider and complex issues involved which reach far beyond the individual and what that individual chooses to eat. Apart from this, it is simply not wise or compassionate to come to a Stage IV discussion boards to effectively announce that you are doing very nicely, thank you very much, because of a book you read about a non dairy diet curing cancer whilst us poor souls are dying because we're obviously too stupid to realize what seems obvious to you.

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2011 06:23AM katie11 wrote: Lobular is notoriously tricky to pick up on scans because of the way it forms. Often the cancer forms in sheets rather tumors which can make it difficult to see them. Scans have always been unreliable for me. I had mets to the abdomen and ovaries that were only found when my ovaries were being removed and hadn't shown up on scans. Similarly I picked up scan results yesterday that said stable overall but blood results say something is going on somewhere, they just don't know what or where. Scary!
